Polarisation Fractions

The following is a list of common ways to calculate the integrated polarisation fraction of a time profile. We will first define \(Q(t), U(t)\) to be our Linear polarisation modes and \(V(t)\) the Circular Polarisation as a function of time, assuming we have averaged in frequency. \(I(t)\) is the total power profile. The uncertainty in these quantities are \(\sigma_{X}\), where \(X\) is the Stokes parameter. For the following I will assume \(Q, U, V\) ect. are the Stokes time profiles, for readibility.

Note: when I say “averaged in frequency”, I mean integrating over frequency then deviding by the number of channels. This will matter if you are after the absolute integrated flux density of Linear/Circular polarisation, however, for calculating fractions, the averaging cancels out.

\(L\) and \(P\)

The linear polarisation is

\[L = \sqrt{Q^{2} + U^2}.\]

Given this functional form, the uncertainty in \(L\) is,

\[\sigma_{L} = \frac{1}{L}\sqrt{Q^{2}\sigma_{Q}^2 + U^{2}\sigma^{2}}.\]

there is a need to debias \(L\) due to the expression used, especially at low signal-to-noise (S/N)

\[\begin{split}L\mathrm{_{d}} = \begin{cases} \sigma_{I}\sqrt{\bigg(\frac{L}{\sigma_{I}}\bigg)^{2} - 1} & \frac{L}{\sigma_{I}} > 1.57 \\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \\ \end{cases}\end{split}\]

The error in \(L\mathrm{_{d}}\) is done in a similar way when calculating the un-debiased Linear polarisation uncertainty \(\sigma_{L}\), but replacing \(L\) with \(L\mathrm{_{d}}\).

Calculating the total polarisation P can be done one of two ways, either by performing a quadratic sum of \(Q,U,V\),

\[P = \sqrt{Q^{2} + U^{2} + V^{2}},\]

or by using \(L\mathrm{_{d}}\)

\[P = \sqrt{L\mathrm{_{d}}^2 + V^{2}}.\]

The second way is easier, and can easily be debised in the same way as with \(L\). The uncertainity is of the same functional form as for \(L\) above, but with \(Q, U\) interchanged with \(L, V\), same goes for the debiased total polarisation.

\(L/I = l\) - Linear Polarisation fraction

\[\bar{l} = \frac{\sum{(Q^{2} + U^{2})}}{\sum{I}}\]

Used often in pulsar/FRB literature, such as Sherman et al, 2024.

\[l^{*} = \frac{\sqrt{(\sum{Q})^{2} + (\sum{U})^{2}}}{\sum{I}}\]

This form has mention in Oswald et al, 2023.

The uncertainty in the integrated Stokes profile \(\sum{X}\) is given by

\[\sigma_{\sum{X}} = \sqrt{\sum_{i}{\sigma_{X, i}^{2}}}\]

if the Stokes profile is mean subtracted, i.e. the mean is zero, then the uncertainty in \(\sum{X}\) is simply the standard deviation multiplied by \(\sqrt{N}\), where \(N\) is the number of samples in the Stokes profile, i.e., N**0.5 * std(\sigma_{X}).

The final uncertainty of some fraction \(X/I\) is

\[\sigma_{X/I} = \frac{X}{I}\sqrt{\frac{\sigma_{X}^{2}}{X^{2}} + \frac{\sigma_{I}^{1}}{I^{2}}}\]

.

It’s easier to work through these equations one at a time then to construct a big explicit equation for each Stokes fraction. It can get messy…

\(V/I = \nu\) - Circular Polarisation fraction

Cicular polarisation can be a pain since the profile can have different signs (+/-). It can also flip sign (change of handedness) over time. This there are a few ways of calculating the Circular polarisation fraction,

\[\bar{\nu} = \frac{\sum{V}}{\sum{I}}\]
\[|\nu|^{*} = |\bar{\nu}|\]
\[\bar{|\nu|} = \frac{\sum{(|V|\mathrm{_{d}})}}{\sum{I}}.\]

The last method is used in Oswald et al, 2023. Additionally, \(|V|\mathrm{_{d}}\) is the debiased absolute Circular polarisation, following Karastergiou et al. 2023 and Posselt et al. 2022. This method seems to be the most “correct” when measuring the fraction of Circular polarisation.

\(P/I = p\) - Total Polarisation fraction (This is the “fun” part)

There are a few ways of calculating \(p\).

The simplest and likely most “correct”, has the following form

\[\bar{p} = \frac{\sum{P\mathrm{_{d}}}}{\sum{I}}.\]

Remember that from the above equations, \(L\mathrm{_{d}}}\) is used to calculate \(P\) which is then also debiased.

The second method seperatley calculates the Stokes \(Q, U\) and \(V\) polarisation fractions, then adds them in quadrature,

\[p^{*} = \sqrt{\bigg(\frac{\sum{Q}}{\sum{I}}\bigg)^{2} + \bigg(\frac{\sum{U}}{\sum{I}}\bigg)^{2} + \bigg(\frac{\sum{V}}{\sum{I}}\bigg)^{2}}.\]

The third method calculates \(P/I\) by first integrating the absolute Stokes V profile

\[\bar{p_{|\nu|}} = \sqrt{\bar{l}^{2} + \bar{|\nu|}^{2}}.\]

This method is less useful, so it’s recommended to use the first two.
